turns.speaker: TRENT
turns.text: It's on...

turns.speaker: SUE
turns.text: ...it's on.

turns.speaker: TRENT
turns.text: It's on.

turns.speaker: SUE
turns.text: ...it's definitely on.

turns.speaker: SUE
turns.text: It is on.

turns.speaker: TRENT
turns.text: ...it is so on.

turns.speaker: SUE
turns.text: Sorry man.

turns.speaker: TRENT
turns.text: Yeah. You probably coulda hit that tonight if you didn't have to drive us home.

turns.speaker: SUE
turns.text: ...Definitely...

turns.speaker: TRENT
turns.text: The bear's got his claws back.

turns.speaker: SUE
turns.text: Be smart about it.

turns.speaker: TRENT
turns.text: I'm telling you. Wait three days...

turns.speaker: SUE
turns.text: You don't have to wait three days...

turns.speaker: TRENT
turns.text: ...Okay, two...

turns.speaker: SUE
turns.text: ...just be smart about it.

turns.speaker: SUE
turns.text: ...Well, then, I guess we don't have to worry about him anymore.

turns.speaker: TRENT
turns.text: Our little baby's growing up...

turns.speaker: TRENT
turns.text: ...One fifty-nine, Two minutes.

turns.speaker: WAITRESS
turns.text: Two vodka martinis, straight up, shaken not stirred, very dry, easy on the water.

turns.speaker: TRENT
turns.text: Beautiful. What time are you off...  ...Christy?

turns.speaker: WAITRESS
turns.text: Six.

turns.speaker: WAITRESS
turns.text: And you?

turns.speaker: TRENT
turns.text: I'll have the Blackbeard over easy.

turns.speaker: WAITRESS
turns.text: I'll be back with the coffee.

turns.speaker: BONASERA
turns.text: Yes, I understand.  I'm listening.

turns.speaker: HAGEN
turns.text: You owe the Don a service.  In one hour, not before, perhaps later, he will be at your funeral parlor to ask for your help.  Be there to greet him.  If you have any objections speak now, and I'll inform him.

turns.speaker: BONASERA
turns.text: Anything...Anything the Godfather wishes.

turns.speaker: HAGEN
turns.text: Good.  He never doubted you.

turns.speaker: BONASERA
turns.text: The Don himself is coming to me tonight?

turns.speaker: HAGEN
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: HAGEN
turns.text: This is Tom Hagen; I'm calling for Don Corleone, at his request.

turns.speaker: BONASERA
turns.text: Yes, I understand I'm listening.

turns.speaker: HAGEN
turns.text: You owe the Don a service.  He has no doubt that you will repay it.

turns.speaker: DON CORLEONE
turns.text: Bonasera, we know each other for years, but this is the first time you come to me for help.  I don't remember the last time you invited me to your house for coffee...even though our wives are friends.

turns.speaker: BONASERA
turns.text: What do you want of me?  I'll give you anything you want, but do what I ask!

turns.speaker: DON CORLEONE
turns.text: And what is that Bonasera?

turns.speaker: DON CORLEONE
turns.text: No.  You ask for too much.

turns.speaker: BONASERA
turns.text: I ask for Justice.

turns.speaker: DON CORLEONE
turns.text: The Court gave you justice.

turns.speaker: BONASERA
turns.text: An eye for an eye!

turns.speaker: DON CORLEONE
turns.text: But your daughter is still alive.

turns.speaker: BONASERA
turns.text: Then make them suffer as she suffers.  How much shall I pay you.

turns.speaker: DON CORLEONE
turns.text: You never think to protect yourself with real friends.  You think it's enough to be an American.  All right, the Police protects you, there are Courts of Law, so you don't need a friend like me. But now you come to me and say Don Corleone, you must give me justice. And you don't ask in respect or friendship.  And you don't think to call me Godfather; instead you come to my house on the day my daughter is to be married and you ask me to do murder...for money.

turns.speaker: BONASERA
turns.text: America has been good to me...

turns.speaker: DON CORLEONE
turns.text: Then take the justice from the judge, the bitter with the sweet, Bonasera.  But if you come to me with your friendship, your loyalty, then your enemies become my enemies, and then, believe me, they would fear you...

turns.speaker: BONASERA
turns.text: Be my friend.

turns.speaker: DON CORLEONE
turns.text: Good.  From me you'll get Justice.

turns.speaker: BONASERA
turns.text: Godfather.

turns.speaker: DON CORLEONE
turns.text: Some day, and that day may never come, I would like to call upon you to do me a service in return.

turns.speaker: BONASERA
turns.text: What do you wish me to do?

turns.speaker: DON CORLEONE
turns.text: I want you to use all your powers, all your skill, as you love me.  I do not want his mother to see him as he is.

turns.speaker: CARLO
turns.text: Understood.  I just wish I was doing more to help out.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: I'll come to you when I need you.

turns.speaker: CARLO
turns.text: Jesus, Connie...Sure, Mike...

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Go back to your house and wait for me...

turns.speaker: CARLO
turns.text: Godfather!

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: You have to answer for Santino.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: You fingered Sonny for the Barzini people.  That little farce you played out with my sister.  Did Barzini kid you that would fool a Corleone?

turns.speaker: CARLO
turns.text: I swear I'm innocent.  I swear on the head of my children, I'm innocent.  Mike, don't do this to me, please Mike, don't do this to me!

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Barzini is dead.  So is Philip Tattaglia, so are Strachi, Cuneo and Moe Greene...I want to square all the family accounts tonight. So don't tell me you're innocent; admit what you did.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Don't be frightened.  Do you think I'd make my sister a widow?  Do you think I'd make your children fatherless?  After all, I'm Godfather to your son.  No, your punishment is that you're out of the family business.  I'm putting you on a plane to Vegas--and I want you to stay there.  I'll send Connie an allowance, that's all. But don't keep saying you're innocent; it insults my intelligence and makes me angry.  Who approached you, Tattaglia or Barzini?

turns.speaker: CARLO
turns.text: Barzini.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Good, good.  Leave now; there's a car waiting to take you to the airport.

turns.speaker: CONNIE
turns.text: What's the matter, Carlo?

turns.speaker: CARLO
turns.text: Shut up.

turns.speaker: CARLO
turns.text: What was that?

turns.speaker: CONNIE
turns.text: Your girl friend.  She says she can't make it tonight.  You lousy bastard you have the nerve to give your whores my telephone number. I'll kill you, you bastard!

turns.speaker: CONNIE
turns.text: You're staying home.  You're not going out.

turns.speaker: CARLO
turns.text: OK, OK.  You gonna make me something to eat at least?

turns.speaker: CONNIE
turns.text: The food is on the table.

turns.speaker: CARLO
turns.text: I'm not hungry yet.

turns.speaker: CONNIE
turns.text: Eat it, it's on the table.

turns.speaker: CARLO
turns.text: Ba Fa Goulle.

turns.speaker: CONNIE
turns.text: BA FA GOULE YOU!

turns.speaker: CARLO
turns.text: You filthy guinea spoiled brat. Clean it up or I'll kick your head in.

turns.speaker: CONNIE
turns.text: Like hell I will.

turns.speaker: CLEMENZA
turns.text: You heard about your father?

turns.speaker: SONNY
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: CLEMENZA
turns.text: The word is out in the streets that he's dead.

turns.speaker: SONNY
turns.text: Where the hell was Paulie, why wasn't he with the Don?

turns.speaker: CLEMENZA
turns.text: Paulie's been a little sick all winter...he was home.

turns.speaker: SONNY
turns.text: How many times did he stay home the last couple of months?

turns.speaker: CLEMENZA
turns.text: Maybe three, four times.  I always asked Freddie if he wanted another bodyguard, but he said no.  Things have been so smooth the last ten years...

turns.speaker: SONNY
turns.text: Go get Paulie, I don't care how sick he is.  Pick him up yourself, and bring him to my father's house.

turns.speaker: CLEMENZA
turns.text: That's all?  Don't you want me to send some people over here?

turns.speaker: SONNY
turns.text: No, just you and Paulie.

turns.speaker: SONNY
turns.text: Clemenza.  You take care of Paulie. I don't ever want to see him again. Understood?

turns.speaker: CLEMENZA
turns.text: Understood.

turns.speaker: SONNY
turns.text: Okay, now you can move your men into the Mall, replace Tessio's people.  Mike, tomorrow you take a couple of Clemenza's people and go to Luca's apartment and wait for him to show.  That crazy bastard might be going after Sollozzo right now if he's heard the news.

turns.speaker: SONNY
turns.text: You take care of Paulie?

turns.speaker: CLEMENZA
turns.text: You won't see Paulie anymore.  He's sick for good this winter.

turns.speaker: CLEMENZA
turns.text: Sollozzo knows Mike's a civilian.

turns.speaker: SONNY
turns.text: OK, but be careful.

turns.speaker: SONNY
turns.text: I want somebody very good, very safe to plant that gun.  I don't want my brother coming out of that toilet with just his dick in his hand.

turns.speaker: CLEMENZA
turns.text: The gun will be there.

turns.speaker: SONNY
turns.text: You're on, kid...I'll square it with Mom your not seeing her before you left.  And I'll get a message to your girl friend when I think the time is right.

turns.speaker: CLEMENZA
turns.text: We gotta move...

turns.speaker: CLEMENZA
turns.text: Mostly it gives witnesses an excuse to change their identification when we make them see the light.  Then you take a long vacation and we catch the hell.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: How bad will it be?

turns.speaker: CLEMENZA
turns.text: Probably all the other families will line up against us.  But, it's alright.  These things have to happen once every ten years or so...gets rid of the bad blood. You gotta stop 'em at the beginning. Like they shoulda stopped Hitler at Munich, they shoulda never let him get away with that, they were just asking for big trouble...

turns.speaker: CLEMENZA
turns.text: We gotta fight sometime.  Let us at least recruit our regimes to full strength.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: No, I don't want to give Barzini an excuse to start fighting.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: He's going to be our lawyer in Vegas.  Nobody goes to him with any other business as of now, this minute.  No reflection on Tom; that's the way I want it.  Besides, if I ever need any advice, who's a better Consigliere than my father.

turns.speaker: CLEMENZA
turns.text: Then in a six month time we're on our own; is that it?

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Maybe less...

turns.speaker: PAULIE
turns.text: You look terrif on the floor!

turns.speaker: CLEMENZA
turns.text: What are you, a dance judge?  Go do your job; take a walk around the neighborhood... see everything is okay.

turns.speaker: CLEMENZA
turns.text: I tol' you to stay put, Paulie...

turns.speaker: PAULIE
turns.text: The guy at the gate's outside...says there's a package...

turns.speaker: CLEMENZA
turns.text: Outside.

turns.speaker: PAULIE
turns.text: Sure.

turns.speaker: PAULIE
turns.text: I'll think about it.

turns.speaker: CLEMENZA
turns.text: Drive while you thinking; I wanna get to the City this month!

turns.speaker: PAULIE
turns.text: Good for ten men...

turns.speaker: CLEMENZA
turns.text: OK, go to Arthur Avenue; I'm suppose to call when I found somethin'.

turns.speaker: PAULIE
turns.text: You think we'll go for that last place?

turns.speaker: CLEMENZA
turns.text: Maybe, or you gotta know now.

turns.speaker: PAULIE
turns.text: Holy cow, I don't gotta know nothing.

turns.speaker: SOLLOZZO
turns.text: My business is heroin, I have poppy fields, laboratories in Narseilles and Sicily, ready to go into production.  My importing methods are as safe as these things can be, about five per cent loss.  The risk is nothing, the profits enormous.

turns.speaker: DON CORLEONE
turns.text: Why do you come to me?  Why do I deserve your generosity?

turns.speaker: SOLLOZZO
turns.text: I need two million dollars in cash...more important, I need a friend who has people in high places; a friend who can guarantee that if one of my employees be arrested, they would get only light sentences.  Be my friend.

turns.speaker: DON CORLEONE
turns.text: What percentages for my family?

turns.speaker: SOLLOZZO
turns.text: Thirty per cent.  In the first year your share would be four million dollars; then it would go up.

turns.speaker: DON CORLEONE
turns.text: And what is the percentage of the Tattaglia family?

turns.speaker: SOLLOZZO
turns.text: My compliments.  I'll take care of them from my share.

turns.speaker: DON CORLEONE
turns.text: So.  I receive 30 per cent just for finance and legal protection.  No worries about operations, is that what you tell me?

turns.speaker: SOLLOZZO
turns.text: If you think two million dollars in cash is just finance, I congratulate you Don Corleone.

turns.speaker: DON CORLEONE
turns.text: No...how a man makes his living is none of my business.  But this proposition of yours is too risky. All the people in my family lived well the last ten years, I won't risk that out of greed.

turns.speaker: SOLLOZZO
turns.text: Are you worried about security for your million?

turns.speaker: DON CORLEONE
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: SOLLOZZO
turns.text: The Tattaglias will guarantee your investment also.

turns.speaker: JOHNNY
turns.text: I kept trying to call you after my divorce and Tom always said you were busy.  When I got the Wedding invitation I knew you weren't sore at me anymore, Godfather.

turns.speaker: DON CORLEONE
turns.text: Can I do something for you still? You're not too rich, or too famous that I can't help you?

turns.speaker: JOHNNY
turns.text: I'm not rich anymore, Godfather, and...my career, I'm almost washed up...

turns.speaker: DON CORLEONE
turns.text: All right, Hollywood...Now tell me about this Hollywood Pezzonovanta who won't let you work.

turns.speaker: JOHNNY
turns.text: He owns the studio.  Just a month ago he bought the movie rights to this book, a best seller.  And the main character is a guy just like me.  I wouldn't even have to act, just be myself.

turns.speaker: DON CORLEONE
turns.text: You take care of your family?

turns.speaker: JOHNNY
turns.text: Sure.

turns.speaker: DON CORLEONE
turns.text: You look terrible.  I want you to eat well, to rest.  And spend time with your family.  And then, at the end of the month, this big shot will give you the part you want.

turns.speaker: JOHNNY
turns.text: It's too late.  All the contracts have been signed, they're almost ready to shoot.

turns.speaker: DON CORLEONE
turns.text: I'll make him an offer he can't refuse.

turns.speaker: DON CORLEONE
turns.text: Is it necessary?

turns.speaker: HAGEN
turns.text: You understand him better than anyone.

turns.speaker: DON CORLEONE
turns.text: I'm sure it's the most generous gift today.

turns.speaker: HAGEN
turns.text: The Senator called--apologized for not coming personally, but said you'd understand.  Also, some of the Judges...they've all sent gifts. And another call from Virgil Sollozzo.

turns.speaker: HAGEN
turns.text: He's his own boss, and very competent.

turns.speaker: DON CORLEONE
turns.text: And with prison record.

turns.speaker: HAGEN
turns.text: Two terms; one in Italy, one in the United States.  He's known to the Government as a top narcotics man. That could be a plus for us; he could never get immunity to testify.

turns.speaker: DON CORLEONE
turns.text: When did he call?

turns.speaker: HAGEN
turns.text: This morning.

turns.speaker: DON CORLEONE
turns.text: On a day like this.  Consiglero, do you also have in your notes the the Turk made his living from Prostitution before the war, like the Tattaglias do now.  Write that down before you forget it.  The Turk will wait.

turns.speaker: DON CORLEONE
turns.text: It is Johnny.  He came all the way from California to be at the wedding.

turns.speaker: HAGEN
turns.text: Should I bring him in.

turns.speaker: DON CORLEONE
turns.text: No.  Let the people enjoy him.  You see?  He is a good godson.

turns.speaker: HAGEN
turns.text: It's been two years.  He's probably in trouble again.

turns.speaker: DON CORLEONE
turns.text: When does my daughter leave with her bridegroom?

turns.speaker: HAGEN
turns.text: They'll cut the cake in a few minutes...leave right after that. Your new son-in-law, do we give him something important?

turns.speaker: DON CORLEONE
turns.text: No, give him a living.  But never let him know the family's business. What else, Tom?

turns.speaker: HAGEN
turns.text: I've called the hospital; they've notified Consiglere Genco's family to come and wait.  He won't last out the night.

turns.speaker: DON CORLEONE
turns.text: What is this nonsense?

turns.speaker: HAGEN
turns.text: It's from Johnny.  It was announced this morning.  He's going to play the lead in the new Woltz Brothers film.

turns.speaker: DON CORLEONE
turns.text: My wife was weeping before she fell asleep, outside my window I saw my caporegimes to the house, and it is midnight.  So, Consigliere of mine, I think you should tell your Don what everyone knows.

turns.speaker: HAGEN
turns.text: I didn't tell Mama anything.  I was about to come up and wake you and tell you.  Just now.

turns.speaker: DON CORLEONE
turns.text: But you needed a drink first.

turns.speaker: HAGEN
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: DON CORLEONE
turns.text: Now you've had your drink.

turns.speaker: HAGEN
turns.text: When I meet with Tattaglia's people; should I insist that all his drug middle-men be clean?

turns.speaker: DON CORLEONE
turns.text: Mention it, don't insist.  Barzini is a man who will know that without being told.

turns.speaker: HAGEN
turns.text: You mean Tattaglia.

turns.speaker: DON CORLEONE
turns.text: Barzini.

turns.speaker: HAGEN
turns.text: He was the one behind Sollozzo?

turns.speaker: DON CORLEONE
turns.text: Tattaglia is a pimp.  He could never have outfought Santino.  But I wasn't sure until this day.  No, it was Barzini all along.

turns.speaker: DON CORLEONE
turns.text: Tom, I never thought you were a bad Consigliere, I thought Santino a bad Don, rest in peace.  He had a good heart but he wasn't the right man to head the family when I had my misfortune.  Michael has all my confidence, as you do.  For reasons which you can't know, you must have no part in what will happen.

turns.speaker: HAGEN
turns.text: Maybe I can help.

turns.speaker: DON CORLEONE
turns.text: Will your girl friend get back to the city all right?

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Tom said he'd take care of it.

turns.speaker: DON CORLEONE
turns.text: What was this for?

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: For bravery.

turns.speaker: DON CORLEONE
turns.text: And this?

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: For killing a man.

turns.speaker: DON CORLEONE
turns.text: What miracles you do for strangers.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: I fought for my country.  It was my choice.

turns.speaker: DON CORLEONE
turns.text: And now, what do you choose to do?

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: I'm going to finish school.

turns.speaker: DON CORLEONE
turns.text: Good.  When you are finished, come and talk to me.  I have hopes for you.

turns.speaker: DON CORLEONE
turns.text: Have you thought about a wife?  A family?

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: DON CORLEONE
turns.text: I understand, Michael.  But you must make a family, you know.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: I want children, I want a family. But I don't know when.

turns.speaker: DON CORLEONE
turns.text: Accept what's happened, Michael.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: I could accept everything that's happened; I could accept it, but that I never had a choice.  From the time I was born, you had laid this all out for me.

turns.speaker: DON CORLEONE
turns.text: No, I wanted other things for you.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: You wanted me to be your son.

turns.speaker: DON CORLEONE
turns.text: Yes, but sons who would be professors, scientists, musicians...and grandchildren who could be, who knows, a Governor, a President even, nothing's impossible here in America.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Then why have I become a man like you?

turns.speaker: DON CORLEONE
turns.text: You are like me, we refuse to be fools, to be puppets dancing on a string pulled by other men.  I hoped the time for guns and killing and massacres was over.  That was my misfortune.  That was your misfortune.  I was hunted on the streets of Corleone when I was twelve years old because of who my father was.  I had no choice.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: A man has to choose what he will be. I believe that.

turns.speaker: DON CORLEONE
turns.text: What else do you believe in?

turns.speaker: DON CORLEONE
turns.text: I told you that it wouldn't escape his eye.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: How did you find out?

turns.speaker: DON CORLEONE
turns.text: I see you have your Luca Brasi.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: I'll need him.

turns.speaker: DON CORLEONE
turns.text: There are men in this world who demand to be killed.  They argue in gambling games; they jump out of their cars in a rage if someone so much as scratches their fender. These people wander through the streets calling out "Kill me, kill me."  Luca Brasi was like that. And since he wasn't scared of death, and in fact, looked for it...I made him my weapon.  Because I was the only person in the world that he truly hoped would not kill him.  I think you have done the same with this man.

turns.speaker: DON CORLEONE
turns.text: Barzini will move against you first.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: How?

turns.speaker: DON CORLEONE
turns.text: He will get in touch with you through someone you absolutely trust.  That person will arrange a meeting, guarantee your safety...

turns.speaker: DON CORLEONE
turns.text: Your wife and children...you're happy with them?

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: DON CORLEONE
turns.text: Good.

turns.speaker: NAZORINE
turns.text: ...a fine boy from Sicily, captured by the American Army, and sent to New Jersey as a prisoner of war...

turns.speaker: DON CORLEONE
turns.text: Nazorine, my friend, tell me what I can do.

turns.speaker: NAZORINE
turns.text: Now that the war is over, Enzo, this boy is being repatriated to Italy.  And you see, Godfather...  He...my daughter...they...

turns.speaker: DON CORLEONE
turns.text: You want him to stay in this country.

turns.speaker: NAZORINE
turns.text: Godfather, you understand everything.

turns.speaker: DON CORLEONE
turns.text: Tom, what we need is an Act of Congress to allow Enzo to become a citizen.

turns.speaker: NAZORINE
turns.text: An Act of Congress!

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Don Tommassino.

turns.speaker: DON TOMMASSINO
turns.text: Michael, why must you do this.  We have been lucky so far, all these months you've been here we've kept your name a secret.  It is from love for your father that I've asked you never to more than an hour from the Villa.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Calo and Fabrizzio are with me; nothing will happen.

turns.speaker: DON TOMMASSINO
turns.text: You must understand that your Father's enemies have friends in Palermo.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: I know.

turns.speaker: DON TOMMASSINO
turns.text: Where are you going?

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Corleone.

turns.speaker: DON TOMMASSINO
turns.text: There is nothing there.  Not anymore.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: I was told that my Grandfather was murdered on its main street; and his murderers came to kill my father there when he was twelve years old.

turns.speaker: DON TOMMASSINO
turns.text: Long ago.  Now there is nothing: the men killed each other in family vendettas...the others escaped to America.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Don Tommassino...I should see this place.

turns.speaker: DON TOMMASSINO
turns.text: That is your birthright...but Michael, use this car.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: No...I would like to walk to Corleone.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Things went badly in Palermo?

turns.speaker: DON TOMMASSINO
turns.text: The younger men have no respect. Things are changing; I don't know what will happen.  Michael, because of the wedding, people now know your name.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Is that why there are more men on the walls?

turns.speaker: DON TOMMASSINO
turns.text: Even so, I don't think it is safe here anymore.  I've made plans to move you to a villa near Siracuse. You must go right away.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: What is it?

turns.speaker: DON TOMMASSINO
turns.text: Bad news from America.  Your brother, Santino.  He has been killed.

turns.speaker: FABRIZZIO
turns.text: You tell us about America.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: How do you know I come from America?

turns.speaker: FABRIZZIO
turns.text: We hear.  We were told you were a Pezzonovanta...big shot.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Only the son of a Pezzonovanta.

turns.speaker: FABRIZZIO
turns.text: Hey America!  Is she as rich as they say?

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: FABRIZZIO
turns.text: Take me to America!  You need a good lupara in America?  You take me, I'll be the best man you got.  "Oh say, can you seeee...By da star early light..."

turns.speaker: FABRIZZIO
turns.text: Hey, beautiful girls!

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Shhhhh.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Get the car.  I'll be leaving in ten minutes.  Where's Calo?

turns.speaker: FABRIZZIO
turns.text: Calo is having a cup of coffee in the kitchen.  Is your wife coming with you?

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: No, she's going home to her family. She'll join me in a few weeks...

turns.speaker: VITELLI
turns.text: You had better bring a few bottles home with you, my friend; you'll need help sleeping tonight.

turns.speaker: FABRIZZIO
turns.text: This one could seduce the devil.  A body! and eyes as big and black as olives.

turns.speaker: VITELLI
turns.text: I know about what you mean!

turns.speaker: FABRIZZIO
turns.text: This was a beauty.  Right, Calo?

turns.speaker: VITELLI
turns.text: Beautiful all over, eh?

turns.speaker: FABRIZZIO
turns.text: And hair.  Black and curly, like a doll.  And such a mouth.

turns.speaker: FABRIZZIO
turns.text: It's the real Thunderbolt, then.

turns.speaker: VITELLI
turns.text: Come Sunday morning:  My name is Vitelli and my house is up there on the hill, above the village.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Why didn't Moe Green meet us at the airport?

turns.speaker: FREDO
turns.text: He had business at the hotel, but he'll drop in for dinner.

turns.speaker: FREDO
turns.text: You look wonderful, kid; really wonderful.  That doctor did some job on your face.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: You look good, too.

turns.speaker: FREDO
turns.text: Ever seen anything like that before?

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: FREDO
turns.text: Mike!  The party starting!

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Come here a minute, Fredo.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Who are those girls?

turns.speaker: FREDO
turns.text: That's for you to find out.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Give them some money and send them home.

turns.speaker: FREDO
turns.text: Mike!

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Get rid of them...

turns.speaker: FREDO
turns.text: Mike, you sure about Moe selling. He never mentioned it to me and he loves the business.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: I'll make him an offer he can't refuse.

turns.speaker: FREDO
turns.text: Tom, you're the Consigliere; you can talk to the Don and advise him.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: The Don has semi-retired.  I'm running the Family business now. So anything you have to say, say it to me.

turns.speaker: HAGEN
turns.text: The old man wants you; Johnny's here...he's got a problem.

turns.speaker: SONNY
turns.text: Okay.  One minute.

turns.speaker: HAGEN
turns.text: Is the hospital covered?

turns.speaker: SONNY
turns.text: The cops have it locked in and I got my people there visiting Pop all the time.  What about the hit list.

turns.speaker: HAGEN
turns.text: What about Luca?  Sollozzo didn't seem worried about Luca.  That worries me.

turns.speaker: SONNY
turns.text: If Luca sold out we're in real trouble.

turns.speaker: HAGEN
turns.text: Has anyone been able to get in touch with him?

turns.speaker: SONNY
turns.text: No, and I've been calling all night. Maybe he's shacked up.

turns.speaker: HAGEN
turns.text: Luca never sleeps over with a broad. He always goes home when he's through.  Mike, keep ringing Luca's number.

turns.speaker: SONNY
turns.text: Tom, you're the Consigliere, what do we do if the old man dies?

turns.speaker: HAGEN
turns.text: Without your father's political contacts and personal influence, the Corleone family loses half its strength.  Without your father, the other New York families might wind up supporting Sollozzo, and the Tattaglias just to make sure there isn't a long destructive war.  The old days are over, this is 1946; nobody wants bloodshed anymore.  If your father dies...make the deal, Sonny.

turns.speaker: SONNY
turns.text: That's easy to say; it's not your father.

turns.speaker: HAGEN
turns.text: I was as good a son to him as you or Mike.

turns.speaker: SONNY
turns.text: Oh Christ Tom, I didn't mean it that way.

turns.speaker: HAGEN
turns.text: We're all tired...

turns.speaker: SONNY
turns.text: OK, we sit tight until the old man can give us the lead.  But Tom, I want you to stay inside the Mall. You too, Mike, no chances.  Tessio, you hold your people in reserve, but have them nosing around the city.  The hospital is yours; I want it tight, fool-proof, 24 hours a day.

turns.speaker: HAGEN
turns.text: Maybe Mike shouldn't get mixed up in this so directly.  You know the old man doesn't want that.

turns.speaker: SONNY
turns.text: OK forget it, just stay on the phone.

turns.speaker: HAGEN
turns.text: Was there a definite proposal?

turns.speaker: SONNY
turns.text: Sure, he wants us to send Mike to meet him to hear his proposition. The promise is the deal will be so good we can't refuse.

turns.speaker: HAGEN
turns.text: What about that Tattaglias?  What will they do about Bruno?

turns.speaker: SONNY
turns.text: Part of the deal: Bruno cancels out what they did to my father.

turns.speaker: HAGEN
turns.text: We should hear what they have to say.

turns.speaker: SONNY
turns.text: No, no Consiglere.  Not this time. No more meetings, no more discussions, no more Sollozzo tricks.  Give them one message: I WANT SOLLOZZO.  If not, it's all out war.  We go to the mattresses and we put all the button men out on the street.

turns.speaker: HAGEN
turns.text: The other families won't sit still for all out war.

turns.speaker: SONNY
turns.text: Then THEY hand me Sollozzo.

turns.speaker: HAGEN
turns.text: Come ON Sonny, your father wouldn't want to hear this.  This is not a personal thing, this is Business.

turns.speaker: SONNY
turns.text: And when they shot me father...

turns.speaker: HAGEN
turns.text: Yes, even the shooting of your father was business, not personal...

turns.speaker: SONNY
turns.text: No no, no more advice on how to patch it up Tom.  You just help me win.  Understood?

turns.speaker: HAGEN
turns.text: I found out about this Captain McCluskey who broke Mike's jaw. He's definitely on Sollozzo's payroll, and for big money. McCluskey's agreed to be the Turk's bodyguard.  What you have to understand is that while Sollozzo is guarded like this, he's invulnerable.  Nobody has ever gunned down a New York Police Captain.  Never.  It would be disastrous.  All the five families would come after you Sonny; the Corleone family would be outcasts; even the old man's political protection would run for cover.  So just...take that into consideration.

turns.speaker: SONNY
turns.text: McCluskey can't stay with the Turk forever.  We'll wait.

turns.speaker: SONNY
turns.text: One of Tattaglia's people?

turns.speaker: HAGEN
turns.text: No.  Our informer in McCluskey's precinct.  Tonight at 8:00 he signed out for Louis' Restaurant in the Bronx.  Anyone know it.

turns.speaker: HAGEN
turns.text: Jesus, I don't know...

turns.speaker: SONNY
turns.text: Can you do it Mike?

turns.speaker: SONNY
turns.text: Pop, they hit us and we hit them back.

turns.speaker: HAGEN
turns.text: We put out a lot of material through our contacts in the Newspapers...about McCluskey's being tied up with Sollozzo in the Drug Rackets...things are starting to loosen up.

turns.speaker: SONNY
turns.text: We'll let the old man take it easy for a couple of weeks.  I want to get things going good before he gets better.  What's the matter with you?

turns.speaker: HAGEN
turns.text: You start operating, the five families will start their raids again.  We're at a stalemate Sonny, your war is costing us a lot of money.

turns.speaker: SONNY
turns.text: No more stalemate Tom, we got the soldiers, we'll match them gun for gun if that's how they want it. They know me for what I am, Tom-- and they're scared of me.

turns.speaker: HAGEN
turns.text: Yes.  That's true, you're getting a hell of a reputation.

turns.speaker: SONNY
turns.text: Well it's war!  We might not be in this shape if we had a real war- time Consiglere, a Sicilian.  Pop had Genco, who do I have?  Hey Tom, hey...hey.  It's Sunday, we're gonna have dinner.  Don't be sore.

turns.speaker: HAGEN
turns.text: Kay, we weren't expecting you.  You should call...

turns.speaker: KAY
turns.text: I've tried calling and writing.  I want to reach Michael.

turns.speaker: HAGEN
turns.text: Nobody knows where he is.  We know he's all right, but that's all.

turns.speaker: KAY
turns.text: What was that?

turns.speaker: HAGEN
turns.text: An accident.  No one was hurt.

turns.speaker: KAY
turns.text: Listen Tom, I let my cab go; can I come in to call another one?

turns.speaker: KAY
turns.text: Will you give this to him.

turns.speaker: HAGEN
turns.text: If I accept that letter and you told a Court of Law I accepted it, they would interpret it as my having knowledge of his whereabouts. Just wait Kay, he'll contact you.

turns.speaker: KAY
turns.text: Will you give this letter to Michael.

turns.speaker: HAGEN
turns.text: Mama, no.

turns.speaker: SOLLOZZO
turns.text: Sonny was hot for my deal, right? You know it's the smart thing to do, too.  I want you to talk Sonny into it.

turns.speaker: HAGEN
turns.text: Sonny will come after you with everything he's got.

turns.speaker: SOLLOZZO
turns.text: The Don was slipping; in the old days I could never have gotten to him.  Now he's dead, nothing can bring him back.  Talk to Sonny, talk to the Caporegimes, Clemenza and Tessio...it's good business.

turns.speaker: HAGEN
turns.text: Even Sonny won't be able to call off Luca Brasi.

turns.speaker: SOLLOZZO
turns.text: I'll worry about Luca.  You take care of Sonny and the other two kids.

turns.speaker: HAGEN
turns.text: I'll try...It's what the Don would want us to do.

turns.speaker: SOLLOZZO
turns.text: Good...then you can go...  I don't like violence.  I'm a businessman, and blood is a big expense.

turns.speaker: HAGEN
turns.text: Mr. Corleone is Johnny's Godfather. That is very close, a very sacred religious relationship.

turns.speaker: WOLTZ
turns.text: Okay, but just tell him this is one favor I can't give.  But he should try me again on anything else.

turns.speaker: HAGEN
turns.text: He never asks a second favor when he has been refused the first. Understood?

turns.speaker: WOLTZ
turns.text: You smooth son of a bitch, let me lay it on the line for you, and your boss.  Johnny Fontane never gets that movie.  I don't care how many Dago, Guinea, wop Greaseball Goombahs come out of the woodwork!

turns.speaker: HAGEN
turns.text: I'm German-Irish.

turns.speaker: WOLTZ
turns.text: Okay my Kraut-Mick friend, Johnny will never get that part because I hate that pinko punk and I'm going to run him out of the Movies.  And I'll tell you why.  He ruined one of Woltz Brothers' most valuable proteges.  For five years I had this girl under training; singing lessons!  Acting lessons!  Dancing lessons!  We spent hundreds of thousands of dollars--I was going to make her a star.  I'll be even more frank, just to show you that I'm not a hard-hearted man, that it wasn't all dollars and cents.  That girl was beautiful and young and innocent and she was the greatest piece of ass I've ever ad and I've had them all over the world.  Then Johnny comes along with that olive oil voice and guinea charm and she runs off.  She threw it all away to make me look ridiculous.  A MAN IN MY POSITION CANNOT AFFORD TO BE MADE TO LOOK RIDICULOUS!

turns.speaker: HAGEN
turns.text: Hello Kay.  Your father's inside, doing some business.  He's been asking for you.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Thanks Tom.

turns.speaker: HAGEN
turns.text: Sure.  Anything I can do for you.

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: No.  I guess I'll see you Christmas. Everyone's going to be out at Long Beach, right?

turns.speaker: HAGEN
turns.text: Right.

turns.speaker: HAGEN
turns.text: What about McCluskey?

turns.speaker: MICHAEL
turns.text: Let's say now that we have to kill McCluskey.  We'll clear that up through our Newspaper contacts later.
